Septic arthritis results from a bacterial infection of the synovial joint space, most commonly by Staphylococcus aureus. The affected joint discloses pain upon passive range of motion, swelling, and erythema on physical examination. Arthrocentesis is indicated for the evaluation of monoarticular erythema and swelling to evaluate for septic arthritis, which characteristically reveals purulent synovial fluid with greater than 50,000 leukocytes/mm3. Serum tests may also show leukocytosis and increased inflammatory markers such as C-reactive protein concentration and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Treatment involves urgent intravenous antibiotics with patients often requiring surgical irrigation of the joint. In this case, the most likely diagnosis is septic arthritis because of the patient's presentation of increased temperature and erythematous joint with pain upon passive range of motion in the absence of reported trauma. The most appropriate next step in management is aspiration of the knee joint to perform joint fluid analysis.

Gout typically presents after consumption of a purine-rich meal or alcohol, which competes with renal excretion of uric acid. Microscopic examination of joint aspiration would typically show negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals and a leukocyte count less than 50,000/mm3.

nbme_correct_explanation: In this patient who has recently converted to a vegan diet, it is most appropriate to begin supplementation with calcium. Patients who follow vegan diets are at increased risk for deficiencies of iron, calcium, zinc, protein, fatty acids, and vitamin B12 (cobalamin). Given that these patients do not have consistent intake of these essential vitamins and minerals, it is appropriate to begin supplementation even prior to the emergence of any symptoms or signs of deficiency. In these patients, the low intake of dietary calcium increases the total body concentration of parathyroid hormone as well as vitamin D. This causes a reuptake of calcium from the bones to maintain appropriate serum concentrations. Over time, this can lead to low bone density and subsequent pathologic fractures.

Magnesium (Choice C) supplementation is not necessary at this time. Patients who follow vegan or vegetarian diets are not generally at risk for magnesium deficiency. This is because high concentrations of magnesium can be found in green leafy vegetables, beans, kale, spinach, bananas, and avocados.

Physical examination may show rhonchi, crackles, decreased breath sounds, and increased tactile fremitus, such as in this patient. nbme_correct_explanation: Overflow incontinence occurs when bladder emptying is impaired, eventually resulting in intravesical hydrostatic pressure overcoming internal and external urinary sphincter dosing pressures, thereby causing the leakage of urine. It can occur due to a variety of causes, including neurologic insults (eg, diabetic neuropathy, stroke, trauma, multiple sclerosis) that result in bladder atony, and bladder outlet obstruction secondary to benign prostatic hyperplasia or a bladder mass. This patient's long history of type 1 diabetes mellitus increases her risk for diabetic neuropathy and overflow incontinence secondary to neurogenic bladder. Patients develop urinary retention with an inability to void and may have loss of urine with Valsalva maneuver or increased abdominopelvic pressure. The diagnosis is established with a urodynamic study, which typically shows an increased postvoid residual volume, such as in this patient with a postvoid residual volume of 800 ml. In contrast to an overactive bladder, which is treated with oxybutynin, overflow incontinence is treated with bethanechol, a muscarinic agent that promotes bladder contraction, or with intermittent catheterization.
nbme_incorrect_explanation:
Functional incontinence (Choice A) describes incontinence secondary to external factors or another condition creating inability to void in a timely manner or inability to recognize the need to void. Several causes of functional incontinence include cognitive disorders such as dementia, movement disorders such as multiple sclerosis or Parkinson disease, physical barriers, or medication effect. This patient has no evidence of a secondary cause of incontinence. Rather, she shows signs of a primary cause of incontinence, overflow incontinence, as evidenced by increased postvoid residual volume.

Stress incontinence (Choice C) is incontinence that is triggered by an increase in intra-abdominal pressure (eg, lifting, sneezing, Valsalva maneuver). Stress incontinence results from urethral hypermobility caused by pelvic floor weakness/prolapse or intrinsic sphincter deficiency. Urethral hypermobility is evidenced on physical examination by deviation greater than 30 degrees from the horizontal of an inserted cotton-tipped applicator with straining. This patient's physical examination is normal, making stress incontinence less likely. In addition, stress incontinence would not have increased postvoid residual volume, which is more suggestive of overflow incontinence. Risk factors for stress incontinence include multiple vaginal deliveries, obesity, and prostate surgery.

Urge incontinence (Choice D), or overactive bladder with incontinence, is caused by detrusor muscle instability and commonly presents with the urge to void followed shortly by the leakage of urine. Patients would have low postvoid residual volume, in contrast with overflow incontinence such as in this patient. Oxybutynin is an antimuscarinic medication used to treat urge incontinence from an overactive bladder and detrusor instability.

Urinary tract infection (Choice E) can present with an overactive bladder (frequency, urgency, urge incontinence). Patients generally also experience dysuria and suprapubic pain. The presence of bacteria and white blood cells on urinalysis is typical. This patient has no dysuria and a normal urinalysis, making urinary tract infection unlikely.

Vesicovaginal fistula (Choice F) can be a consequence of gynecologic surgery, pelvic malignancy, or radiation therapy. It typically presents with painless urinary leakage from the bladder into the vagina. On pelvic examination, a pool of urine is typically present in the vaginal canal. This patient's physical examination shows no abnormalities, making vesicovaginal fistula less likely.

nbme_correct_explanation: Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is a disorder of red blood cell membrane proteins that limits the ability of the cell to conform when passing through narrow capillary beds. This results in early removal of the red blood cells by the spleen and a resultant hemolysis, which causes normocytic, hemolytic anemia. HS is the most common disorder of the red blood cell membrane and is frequently seen in people of European descent. A family history of HS is generally present. Autosomal dominant mutations in ankyrin, spectrin, and band erythrocyte membrane proteins cause HS through loss of the normal connection between the inner membrane skeleton and the outer lipid bilayer. Patients typically present with fatigue, global weakness, and pallor, with associated splenomegaly and jaundice on physical examination. Laboratory studies generally show anemia and indirect hyperbilirubinemia along with an abnormal osmotic fragility test and eosin-5'-maleimide analysis on flow cytometry. Patients are prone to development of bilirubin gallstones because of the high levels of indirect bilirubin. Blood smear shows rounded red blood cells without central pallor. Splenic congestion and sequestration are hallmarks of moderate-to-severe disease. Splenectomy is indicated to reduce the degree of premature red blood cell consumption (i.e., extravascular hemolysis) and the risk for sequestration crises.
